title: Before 1 February 2020, will the United Kingdom leave the European Union?
possible_answers: Yes, with a Withdrawal Agreement with the EU in force
Yes, without a Withdrawal Agreement with the EU in force
No, with the UK revoking its invocation of Article 50
No, without the UK revoking its invocation of Article 50
correct_answer: Yes, with a Withdrawal Agreement with the EU in force

And with the EU Parliament's approval granted, everybody who's less than 100% on this is just raising my accuracy score at the expense of their own.

EU parliament gives final approval to Brexit deal BRUSSELS (Reuters) - The European Parliament on Wednesday gave its final approval to Britain’s divorce deal from the bloc, paving the way for Brexit to take place on Friday. The chamber broke into singing Auld Lang Syne, a traditional Scottish song to bid farewell, after voting 621 for versus 49 against the Brexit deal, with 13 abstentions. Baczynska, G. & Emmott, R. (2020). EU parliament gives final approval to Brexit deal. Reuters. World News. January 29, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-parliament-approval/eu-parliament-gives-final-approval-to-brexit-deal-idUSKBN1ZS2K9

European Parliament ratified the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement on Wed evening, 29 Jan 2020. This was the final hurdle for Brexit to take effect as scheduled on 31 Jan 2020. The only way for any of the other three alternatives above to happen is if the UK suddenly changed its mind on the Withdrawal Agreement, causing the whole process to start over. That seems rather unlikely to me.

Members of the European Parliament will vote on the Brexit agreement today as Britain’s long departure from the European Union faces its final legislative hurdle. Barring an asteroid striking Brussels, MEPs will pass the deal, and Britain will formally leave on Friday. But all that means is that Europe’s attention can turn to the next stage: deciding Britain’s future relationship with the bloc. The European Commission has spent the past week outlining its negotiating positions on topics from fish to financial services. The end-of-year deadline for negotiations is impossibly tight, yet the British government has repeatedly ruled out any extension. Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief negotiator, has already fallen back on his favourite catchphrase that the “clock is ticking”. If the topics sound familiar, that is because they are. Nearly four years after the Brexit vote there is still no clear picture of what the relationship between the EU and Britain will look like.
Any Wildcard trouble should have been taken into consideration.
the Withdrawal agreement was signed by PM Boris Johnson on Jan 24.

Adjustment to account for House of Lords capitulation:  despite all amendments overturned by House of Commons earlier today, HoL has decided not to press the issue, so legislation has cleared Parliament.  Next step is ratification by EU Parliament, slated for 29 Jan.  At this point, only token resistance expected, but still the potential for political maneuvers to delay their ratification past the specified timeline:  wouldn't stop UK's exit, but would meet the threshold for lack of 'Withdrawal Agreement with the EU'.

I guess some EU body could object to something in the UK's Withdrawal Bill being different to that which was agreed in the WA between the EU and UK in November, but as the UK WB has been published and the EU has not objected to the differences yet, it seems that the EU is content. So I struggle to see why the UK will not leave on 31st Jan with the WA in place

In terms of the Lisbon Treaty, Article 50 TEU, on February 2016, "If  no  agreement  is  concluded  within  two  years,thatstate'smembership ends automatically, unless the European Council and the MemberState concerned decide jointly to extend this period". It is most likely that Lisbon Treaty will be fulfilled, and there will be no more request to extend the due date.

Reporting seems to indicate only token resistance internal to the EU Parliament, so failure for them to ratify UK's bill seems minimal (-2% from last forecast).  House of Lords just finished 2nd reading of bill and press reports appear to indicate heightened concern with some areas of the bill.  They have relatively few instances where they've successfully opposed the gov't, however one of their recent pushbacks centered on Brexit regulations (https://www.ucl.ac.uk/constitution-unit/sites/constitution-unit/files/201920-defeat1.pdf).   It seems they still could delay passage of the bill beyond 31 Jan by pushing amendments back to House of Commons.

With the recent solid re-election of the Conservative Party, they probably feel fairly confident in the popular support for BREXIT as indicated by the MPs vote in favor of the updated withdrawal agreement in Dec 2019 (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-32810887). However, the EU has not approved the agreement yet.

Although doubtful depending on sources, it appears there is some potential for the House of Lords to slow passage of the Withdrawal Agreement, slowing down the UK's ultimate passage of the bill beyond 1 Feb.  While passage remains highly likely, there also appears to be an undercurrent of resistance in the EU parliament which wouldn't stop UK's exit from the EU, but would mean they do so without the benefit of a fully ratified Withdrawal Agreement in place.

“First, Downing Street insists it will not extend the transition in any circumstances. The EU’s 27 member states will only agree on the commission’s mandate to negotiate on their behalf by the end of February. The cabinet and Whitehall will also need time to settle on a final policy. The ratification of the deal will probably take two to three months. In a best-case scenario, that leaves March to September – seven months – to strike an agreement. It’s an understatement to suggest this might not be long enough … The challenge Johnson is setting himself is immense. The risk of a no-deal cliff edge at the end of the year will remain a key concern. Second, many at the top of the government see diverging from EU rules as the big prize of Brexit. While legislation enshrining existing EU standards in the areas of workers’ rights and the environment is likely, it’s doubtful this government will agree to follow EU rules in the future.  Boris Johnson and Ursula von der Leyen had [a “positive” exploratory meeting](https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2020/jan/08/ursula-von-der-leyen-uk-deadline-makes-full-brexit-deal-impossible) on the next round of Brexit talks, making a concerted effort to put the divisions of the past three years behind them.
The new president of the European Commission said the two sides should focus on mutual interests, and both leaders reportedly agreed that there could be common ground on the climate crisis, human rights, and security. Von der Leyen [said in a speech before the meeting](https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/SPEECH_20_3) that such a timeframe was essentially impossible if Britain wanted a comprehensive agreement, and reiterated that the UK would not be allowed to have its cake and eat it:
The more divergence there is, the more distant the partnership has to be. Without free movement of people, you cannot have free movement of capital, goods, and services. Without a level playing field on environment, labor, taxation and state aid, you cannot have the highest-quality access to the world’s largest single market. ================

House of Commons passes Brexit bill for UK departure from EU on January 31 Jamieson (2020) Jan. 10, stated that: Britain's House of Commons has voted to pass the Brexit bill — finally paving way for the UK's January 31 departure from the European Union after years of political deadlock (Para. 1). MPs voted 330-231 to pass the EU Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which will become law once it is approved, as expected, by the upper House of Lords. The bill's passage is a victory for Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who has vowed that Britain will leave the EU on the scheduled date. Britain voted narrowly to leave the EU in a 2016 referendum. But before the Dec. 12 election, lawmakers repeatedly defeated attempts by both Johnson and predecessor Theresa May to secure backing for their Brexit blueprints (Para. 1-4). *
Reference
*
Jamieson, A. (2020). House of Commons passes Brexit bill for UK departure from EU on January 31. Euronews. United Kingdom. Jan. 10, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.euronews.com/2020/01/09/house-of-commons-passes-brexit-bill-for-uk-departure-from-eu-on-january-31

Boris Johnson was elected solely to leave the EU; he will have no political capital left if he doesn't. He will pass some slight variation of a "withdrawa agreement" which May proposed, and then the hard negotiations regarding trade will begin afterwards.

The House of Commons voted today to approve the Brexit Bill, sending it to the House of Lords. Based on the length of negotiations and the political turmoil associated with developing an Agreement, I don't see a withdrawal occurring without the Bill being voted and approved. Though most media suggest that the House of Lords will easily approve the bill, there do  appear to be two to three issues that politicians may try to leverage during final negotiating and voting. As such, there would be a chance that the bill may not pass by the 31st deadline. Finally, if I understand the terminology of Article 50 correctly, revoking the invocation of Article 50 presumes that the UK would remain a member of the EU. Based on today's vote, that doesn't appear to be a consideration.

It depends on what "leave the EU" means.  "The United Kingdom is now scheduled to leave the European Union no later than 31 January 2020" --> not really.  What will happen on the 31st of January isn't UK leaving the EU. The withdrawal agreement itself states that the actual "leave" must be in place by the 31st of Dec 2020, in 11 months, not now. During those 11 months the EU legislation will still apply in the UK and UK will continue to contribute to the funding of EU - that's not really "leaving" it, is it? Sure, it's an important step and so on, but in practice any EU citizen traveling/working or having whatever kind of relationship with the UK is not going to feel any differences, yet. I make my prediction considering that what you're trying to ask is "will the withdrawal agreement actually pass through the UK parliament and will it also be ratified by the EU before the 1st of Feb 2020 - paving the way for what we hope to be a nice Brexit by 31 Dec 2020?" (having a nice brexit with all the treaties renegotiated is close to an impossible task to do in 11 months - check out historical negotiations over similar treaties even, signed even between friendly states and how long they took to get recognized & signed by both sides, especially when you have 750+ treaties to renegociate) Considering the position Johnson has now and the support he got, the agreement will get passed through the UK parliament, that's why I attribute a 97% probability for it. Check below: (1)https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-51014639
(2)https://www.dw.com/en/will-boris-johnson-get-brexit-done-in-2020/a-51776967
(3)https://www.dw.com/en/opinion-uk-on-course-for-a-hard-brexit/a-51757381 There's a chance of something going wrong before the 1st of Feb, slim, pushing for an exit but messing up the agreement drafted. 2% for that, not more, imho. There's also a chance of a "miracle", 1% is high, but since I find it to be above 0.5% - I'll place it here. UK is not able to revoke the invocation of Article 50 (except if they cast a mass amnesia dust at a world wide level and erase everything out of the media for the past 2,5 years), but without revoking it, there's still a chance they won't leave EU before 1st of Feb 2020.

FYI from Economist 
“Parliament today resumes debate on the European Union withdrawal bill, following last month’s general election. Since Boris Johnson’s Tories now have an 80-seat Commons majority, it should pass swiftly without significant amendment. This means Britain will formally leave the EU on January 31st, when Mr Johnson will insist Brexit is “done”. He even plans to stop using the B-word. Yet in reality Britain will move into an 11-month transition period when it remains subject to all EU rules. It must also negotiate a big free-trade deal with the bloc. Few trade experts believe this can be done in the time, but Mr Johnson rules out extending the transition. The likeliest outcome is a bare-bones deal for goods, with nothing for services (some 80% of the British economy). Even for this the EU will demand extensive regulatory alignment, which Mr Johnson rejects. The risk of a no-trade-deal Brexit at the end of 2020 is thus serious.”

Britain minting Brexit coins for 31 January deadline Sangster (2019) December 27, stated that: A new 50 pence coin to commemorate Brexit has been ordered by the government — the third one slated for production (Para. 1). A royal proclamation issued in the name of the Queen at the start of the month approved the production of “coins in gold, silver, and cupro-nickel marking the United Kingdom’s exit from the European Union.” The coins will be inscribed with the date of ‘31 January 2020’, the day the UK is set to officially leave the European Union. A spokesperson for the Treasury told Bloomberg the commemorative coins “will be introduced into circulation on the day the UK leaves the EU.” It marks the third time the government has planned to mint commemorative Brexit 50ps. The new coins were originally planned for 29 March, 2019 but the delay to Brexit scuppered these plans. They hadn’t yet been minted when the Brexit deadline was pushed back to October 31 (Para. 1-5).
*
Reference
*
Sangster, K. (2019). Britain minting Brexit coins for 31 January deadline. Yahoo. Finance. UK. December 27, 2019. Retrieved from
https://finance.yahoo.com/news/brexit-coin-50-pence-31-january-093833851.html

I'm putting a Tory majority probability at 75%, and in that case 95% chance Johnson et all will then have the votes to push through the withdrawal agreement by end January ... giving 71%.  I think a no-deal exit is currently less than 1%, assuming that if they don't have the votes for the WAB, the opposition will stop the default exit.  A 'people's vote' seems still plausible, but not in the time limit of the question, the revocation option I also put at less than 1%.  Leaving 29% for the final option--extension, certainly likely in the event of a Labour/Lib Dem coalition, or even a hung parliament.

Starting to build out the conditional probabilities here based on tomorrow’s elections.  I see 3 initial scenarios:
- conservative majority (70%)
- Labour/liberal democrat majority (1%)
- no majority (29%) From there, I think there is a high probability that a conservative majority pushes the withdrawal agreement through (90%). I see a Labour majority as equally likely to get an extension or force a referendum. In the case of a referendum I think the odds of it passing are 50% (could probably do better with more research - I’d say risks are on the upside). I see a no majority outcome as most likely to get an extension (65%) vs a hard Brexit.  Building out the tree, this gets me to the following probabilities:
Extend: 24%
Withdraw (with agreement): 64%
Withdraw (without agreement): 9%
Revoke Article 50: 3% Given that my above analysis has no scope limit, I moved the revoke probability from 3% to 0% and put the balance in extend. This update reflects an increasing probability of Labour spoiling the Conservatives’ party.

Before 1 February 2020, will the United Kingdom leave the European Union? @JPJCB & @paulmynott have provided concise analysis and moved me more towards a bi-modal stance. I'll sit here until the election. Current polling doesn't look very definitive.

The outcome of the forthcoming election is the key variable determining my forecast. If the Conservatives win a majority (which I judge to be 55% likelihood), then leaving with a withdrawal agreement is highly likely as all Conservative candidates have pledged to vote for the deal. If the Conservatives are only the largest party (but no majority) or Labour win a majority/largest party then a further extension, i.e. no without the UK revoking, becomes most likely since the chances of a referendum increase and Labour have pledged that this would take place beyond January 31st 2020. The UK leaving on January 31st without a deal is only likely if the Brexit party puts in a strong showing - polls suggest this is not likely - or the EU decides not to grant another extension. The UK leaving before January 31st having revoked its invocation of Article 50 relies on another referendum with a remain vote having taken place before January 31st which is highly unlikely.

Still depends on the elections, after which it could well be: All change, mind the gap Cannot see Labour or a coalition puttiing article 50 back in its box by Feb 1 - a possibility further down the line, but not in 40 days (and nights)  -  dare say totals will be revised as the path becomes more clear, goal posts shift, alliances form, fluxes pulse and wane And through the good times and bad there could be more twists than Oliver this Christmas, said Carrol...  Look there is the ghost of Christmas yet to come!!!  Where cried the boy?  Behind you

Option 2 and 3 are unlikely. No likely post-election government would do 2 or 3. EU could refuse a requested extension leading to 2, to but it is probably not in their interest to do so, especially in light of a change in the composition of U.K. government, so I have put this higher than 3, but still very low. That leaves 1 and 4 as likely. Polls suggest increase in Conservative MPs, making Johnson’s plan to leave by February more feasible, and giving him over a month to get through Parliament. This would suggest 1 as the most likely option. But! There are many possible ways to get to 4 and any unexpected events are likely to push towards that so on that basis I have to put that as high as 1.

The smart money would have to be on Boris of Brexit  - having said that the movement to stay in the EU is very strong and Brexit was dubbed Hotel California over two years ago (you can check out anytime)  The fact that this has now dragged on for three years shows just how much resistance there is, one could also blame the EU for pushing issues and polices on people....   and so on...  and so on It is obviously more complex than that and I dare say that there will be a lot of changes in the seating arrangements after the election dust has settled

I disagree with the sentiment that Conservatives will take their time pushing through Brexit if they get the necessary majority - I think they’ll push hard to get it done in one vote.

By the time the dust clears after election and a new government is in place there will not be enough time for them to renegotiate anything of substantial change from what is presently had that the members will be able to agree upon in a majority. The new government will need more time to get their bearings straight, hopefully listen to what the people want and take it into consideration before such a decisive moment in not just UK but world history to materialize.

At this stage a small majority for the Conservative party seems a plausible outcome of the election if not certain. Once that is in place, it then just requires a brief debate and a vote to pass the WAB to make Brexit in a formal sense inevitable, form the UK side. There will be noise etc. from the Euro parliament but I cannot see that being enough to block the ratification from the EU side, once the ratification is certain from the UK side.

There is no way BJ can crash out of EU even with a new parliament with more Cons MPs - it has been tried before with May and BJ but failed.  Similarly for revoking Article 50. The "No, without the UK revoking..." essentially means another delay.  That is ridiculous and if UK asks for another delay, Macron will try to stop it.

The main issue with all the mess is that country is more or less equally divided over Brexit. When all this started three years ago, the country was more inclined to go for it but when they learned all the pitfalls and direct/indirect effects, they learned that it may not be beneficial as they thought. However, because of snowball effect and contribution by leaders similar to BJ, Brexit is more likely happen than not. It may not be sustainable for long term but they are more inclined to experience the real cost and then decide on course correction.

If the Tories win a large majority they can pass their deal, then it will go to Europe for ratification. 1 in 3 chance of tory majority, plus quick ratification. 1/6 chance that a technical extension is required because the Walloons are playing silly buggers or something. 1/2 chance of Labour/Lib Dems/SNP denying Tories a majority (if polls swing against them and haggling either leading to an altered deal or referendum.

Boris Johnson will not endorse the NoDeal exit now. But he endorses the deal that is virtually the same as Teresa Mays deal. Boris is sabotaging his chances of being re elected so....Nigel Farage will kick his arse in the elections. Then we will have a minority govt again that can not pass anything into law.

I am starting this with a simple scenario tree. Election, Dec 12:
1. Conservatives form government (either with majority or in coalition for simplicity) - 90%
2. Opposition forms government (e.g. Labour with LibDems) - 10% Withdrawal Agreement Bill
1.a. Passes and legislation is adopted in time (65%)  —> *First bucket* 
1.b Fails (35%) Renegotiation of WAB under cons government
1.b.a. New government coalition manages to make changes to WAB necessary to pass it in time (30%) —> *First Bucket*
1.b.b. New government fails to re-negotiate with EU in time (70%) 1.b.b.a New government is willing to crash out (30%)  —> *Second bucket*
1.b.b.b. New government is unwilling to crash out (70%) —> *Third or Fourth buckets* (assuming revoking A50 is the slightly less likely option due to opposition to it in the past) Alternative branch:
For simplicity for now I am assuming that under a new non-conservative-led government the WAB will fail. A referendum may be scheduled or this new government will try to renegotiate with the EU. In both cases an extension will be required. I am assuming slightly higher chance for an extension rather than the revoking A50 as the latter has shown to be unpopular in the past. First bucket = 58.5% + 9.5% = 68%
Second bucket = 7%
Third bucket OR Fourth bucket = 15% + 10% = 25% Everyone is welcome to provide thoughts on the branches of the scenario tree or the probabilities.

It continues to be difficult to guess out the ultimate extent of the UK's ineptitude in handling this matter, but sooner or later one expects that at least a couple of EU members will tire of this dance and vote against yet another extension.
If they can't beat South Africa how will they muddle thru this to a completed end?

PM negotiates a new WA & parliament approves it (60%) =               60% Yes + WA
PM negotiates a new WA but parliament demands 2nd ref (40%)
         referendum accepts new WA (50%) =                                           20% Yes + WA
        referendum rejects new WA (50%)                                           
            Brexit w/ no WA (35%)                                                                  7% Yes + no WA
            revoke A50  (35%)                                                                          7% No + revoke
            request extend A50  (30%)                                                           6% No + extend A50 Basically, I think 
-BJ & Tories will gain seats after GE which will increase odds of acceptance of a new WA
-If BJ & Tories don't gain enough seats, opposition may force a 2nd referendum
-the odds of the referendum passing are about 50/50, depending on how the referendum is worded.

The way I’m reading these:
“Yes, with a Withdrawal Agreement with the EU in force”: Brexit with the deal Johnson got last month
“Yes, without a Withdrawal Agreement with the EU in force”: hard no deal Brexit
“No, with the U.K. revoking it’s invocation of Article 50”: another referendum in which the U.K. votes not to leave
“No, without the U.K. revoking it’s invocation of Article 50”: another extension I think the current deal passing is the most likely outcome because as of the last vote it enjoys plenty of support in principle, the EU is unwilling to renegotiate, and BOE and private sector economists are saying Brexit-related uncertainty is doing as much or more economic damage than the Brexit itself. A no deal Brexit seems less likely for the reasons mentioned above and because the resulting MAAD dynamic makes it a desirable outcome for nobody. I think the extension game will continue if a deal can’t be reached. That being said, the EU requires unanimous support for an extension and patience is wearing thin with France and Germany. This may be enough to push the U.K. out under the argument “they had plenty of chances”. Lastly, I think a revocation is least likely at this point. I’ll be watching the elections and public opinion closely. If the conservatives get a majority, I think the bill passes. A Labour majority is a little more uncertain. At this point, their calculus might be that anything is better than a No Deal in which case they may try and tweak some elements but pass the deal because they think the EU will in support another extension/renegotiation. On the other hand, if Labour can get sufficient majority (2/3 I think) they may call a second referendum.
I am a glutton for pjnishment. Here we go again. Into the brexit pond.
